newsitem.title: FRANCE: Algeria votes party law barring Islamists.
newsitem.headline: Algeria votes party law barring Islamists.

text.p: Algeria's government-appointed Transitional National Council on Tuesday approved a law that bans political parties from having a political platform based on Islam, the official Algerian news agency APS said.

The bill, accepted by the quasi-parliament in a special session called by President Liamine Zeroual, is an attempt to realign the political field after 1992 elections were cancelled when an Islamic party took the lead.
Since then some 60,000 people have died in violence between Moslem rebels and government forces.
Many Algerians blame the current bloody struggle over power on a previous law that allowed the radical Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) to enter politics.

That law ushered in the start of Algeria's democratic experiment in 1989, allowing more than 60 political parties from various shades to compete for power. The now-banned FIS did well enough to lead the 1992 national elections.

The new political party law also stipulates that every party should have a certain amount of supporters in at least 25 provinces among the country's 48 provinces. Some politicians say this will mean the end of many parties.
The law gives two legal Islamist parties, Nahda and Hamas, two months to change their manifestos to avoid running afoul of the legislation, political sources said.
